Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Extending the potential for hydrogen isotope tracers in ecology: experiments, biochemistry and field studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The hydrogen isotopic composition of animal tissues has become as a valuable tool in the investigation of animal movements and the study of habitat use. However, the biochemical foundation needed for animal ecologists to confidently apply isotopic analyses to ecological problems has yet to be adequately revealed. This project will address that knowledge gap by advancing our understanding of fundamental processes controlling isotopic composition in tissues of vertebrates. New methodologies will be applied to analyze compound-specific isotopes of individual amino acids in animal tissues and to determine whether hydrogen can be directly routed from dietary amino acids into tissues. Biosynthetic mechanisms responsible for determining hydrogen isotope patterns observed in bulk tissues will be explored in a series of laboratory experiments. Results from this research will address the magnitude and degree of variation in isotope discrimination for animal tissues, and the biochemical mechanism of hydrogen incorporation into an animal's tissue from its food and water. To accomplish this work, the fish species tilapia will be reared in tanks with water and food components having unique and controlled isotopic compositions. The isotopic composition of individual amino acids, particularly those that are indispensible for growth, will be measured to trace incorporation from dietary protein, carbohydrate, lipid, and water into fish tissues. The research will be extended to a population-based study of black-throated blue warblers, for which the hydrogen isotopic composition of individual amino acids from feather, bone, and liver tissues will be measured from three locations that span the continental range for this bird species in North America.

Results from this project will advance a new methodology and provide foundational knowledge for isotopic approaches to the study of animal ecology and behavior. The project will develop and teach a graduate level course on isotopic ecology, involve undergraduate students in the laboratory research, and conduct outreach to high school biology classes to foster understanding of biochemical ecology. It will also support workshops designed to raise awareness of the potential uses of stable isotopes in the biological sciences and set the stage for future collaboration with researchers in several Latin American countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The hydrogen isotopic composition (d2H) of animal tissues has emerged as a valuable tool in the investigation of animal movements and the study of habitat use. The biochemical foundation needed for animal ecologists to confidently apply d2H analyses to ecological problems has yet to be adequately revealed. Our proposal to uncover some of the fundamental components of d2H analysis emphasizes experiments in vertebrates, primarily birds, as d2H analyses have proved to be of high value in migration studies, and fish, which will be raised in waters with controlled isotopic compositions. Preliminary results from new methods that the PIs developed to analyze compound-specific isotopes of individual amino acids in animal tissues indicate that hydrogen can be directly routed from dietary amino acids into tissues. However, there are still many unknowns concerning how H isotopes are fractionated. Therefore, we proposed to explore the biosynthetic mechanisms responsible for patterns observed in our experimental bulk tissue datasets. We accomplished this through laboratory experiments that addressed two problems: 1) the magnitude and degree of variation in discrimination factors for avian tissues—blood, muscle, liver, and bone collagen, and 2) the biochemical mechanism of hydrogen incorporation from an animal’s food and water. The research also examined hydrogen isotopic discimination in tissues (feather, bone, muscle, and liver) and potential sources of hydrogen (water, plants, and insects) from wild populations of black-throated blue warblers (Dendroica caerulescens) collected from our field site in North Carolina. Lastly, our experiments address a significant analytical problem by determining the isotopic exchange of hydrogen in these tissues, and the results of these experiments can then be used to correct for spatial and temporal variation in atmospheric water vapor.

The results from our tilapia experiment highlight some important ecological and physiological issues that have not been previously explored regarding how animals assimilate hydrogen from various sources (water and food) and use it to synthesize tissues. Perhaps the most unique aspect of our study was the use of both d2H and carbon (d13C) isotope analyses to quantify the relative contribution of various dietary macromolecules––protein, lipids, carbohydrates––to tissue synthesis. This approach allowed us to examine the extent of protein routing, but perhaps more importantly demonstrates that non-protein dietary components contribute hydrogen to tissue synthesis. Our study is also one of the first to estimate hydrogen isotope trophic discrimination factors (D2Hnet) for two tissues (muscle and liver) commonly analyzed by ecologists. Continued analysis of d2H values of individual amino acids that will be performed by co-PI Fogel in 2016 will provide further insight into how animals assimilate hydrogen and use this element to build/maintain their tissues.

Data from the field portion of our project is better characterizing variation in d2H values among components (water, primary producers, primary consumers, secondary consumers) of a single food web. Identifying what factors control these patterns is important for refining the use of hydrogen isotope analysis as an ecological tool to study animal movement/migration and resource use within and among ecosystems. We are also exploring variation in d2H among metabolically active (muscle and liver) and metabolically inert (feather) bird tissues that represent different time periods in the life of an individual.
